Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of epigenetic gene regulation by the Drosophila COMPASS-like complex

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The genetic code of every living organism is contained within chromosomes, referred to collectively as the genome. In all eukaryotes, the genome is compacted into the nucleus through the formation of condensed molecules known as chromatin. The smallest individual units of compaction are known as nucleosomes that are comprised of 147 base pairs of DNA wrapped around an octamer of small basic histone proteins. In order for regulatory factors and enzymes to access the genetic code and properly regulate processes essential for normal development and cell survival, the nucleosomes need to be moved aside or directly modified on specific amino acid residues in a process termed chromatin remodeling. The enzymes and other proteins that carry out chromatin remodeling are ancient and remarkably conserved, with increasing complexity from single celled organisms up through vertebrates. The overall impact of this project will be a better understanding of how chromatin remodeling controls expression of the information that is encoded within the genome. In addition, high school, undergraduate and graduate students will participate in mentored research. Women and minorities will be highly represented. Multidisciplinary training and education are vital to prepare for diverse science careers and this project employs the unique tools currently available for Drosophila studies. Students will be trained in molecular and developmental genetics, biochemistry, molecular biology and bioinformatics, structural and developmental biology. The project will enhance interactions among faculty scientists within the institution and with students at multiple undergraduate institutions to explore the rapidly emerging field of bioinformatics. Undergraduate students will be tasked with learning new informatics tools and approaches using experimental data derived from this project.

In order to define the histone recognition and binding properties of Cmi and related mammalian domains and elucidate the potential mechanism of COMPASS-like complex targeting to gene enhancers, collaborative structural studies that include X-ray crystallography and nuclear magnetic resonance of the histone recognition domains and targeted mutagenesis combined with in vitro measurements of binding affinities and in vivo chromatin association will be employed. The project also uses next-generation high throughput chromatin and RNA analyses (ChIP-Seq, RNA-Seq) and target gene studies. ChIP-Seq using chromatin from cmi mutant animals will enable correlation of epigenetic marks with Cmi function and align the RNA-Seq gene expression data with chromatin binding to address key developmental functions. Tissue-specific targeted removal of both cmi and trr and overexpression of cmi using unique genetic tools developed for these studies will allow for direct testing of COMPASS-like functions on target genes. Leading edge chromatin technologies that examine physical connections between distant gene regions will elucidate novel regulatory roles for the Drosophila COMPASS-like complex in facilitating enhancer-promoter communication necessary for proper gene control. These studies will help to reveal essential and foundational properties of chromatin remodeling and modifying complexes and provide critical insight into the mechanisms of developmental gene regulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most important and complex tasks of a developing organism is the precise orchestration of gene regulation events that control the precise timing and level of gene expression. Proper animal development involves precise intercellular signaling and coordination among cells and tissues, processes that require fine tuned gene expression. Although studied for decades, many of the mechanisms of proper gene regulation in the natural context of the cell nucleus are still not well understood, owing to the complex controls that both turn genes on/off and precisely regulate their levels. Our project has focused on examining one of the key regulators of this gene modulatory system, the COMPASS-like MLR (MLL3/4, TRR) complex, using the fruitfly Drosophila melanogaster genetic model organism. This large and very highly conserved complex serves to mark or establish all eukaryotic enhancers, the small DNA elements that are essential to modulate gene transcription. Essential features of MLR complexes include interactions with DNA binding transcription factors, recognition and binding of histones (the proteins that compact DNA), enzymatic modification of specific histone residues and recruitment of other enzymes that are involved in turning on enhancers. The biological importance of understanding the fundamental mechanisms of enhancer control by the MLR complex is profound, as loss of the complex in both germline and somatic tissues is associated with developmental defects as well as human cancers, respectively. In most eucaryotes, the histone recognition and enzyme functions are together in single proteins; whereas, in Drosophila, these features are separated into two proteins, Cmi and Trr, that resulted from a gene-splitting event during insect evolution. This splitting has made Drosophila an ideal system in which to study how these functions work interdependently to control gene expression in all eucaryotes. Our project has generated critical insights into how the complex recognizes specific histones embedded in enhancer DNA regions and controls how those enhancers will be used to drive gene transcription. We comprehensively mapped all locations within the genome that the Drosophila MLR complex binds and examined the patterns of binding at different developmental stages to see how the complex functions to control enhancers. Using genetic tools, we depleted or removed the complex from cells and tissues at various times in development and determined the consequences on gene expression and the impacts on histone marking (also known as epigenetics). Questions regarding how these marks are precisely placed (including complex recruitment and stability at enhancers), interpreted and utilized to both activate and repress transcription are among the most profoundly challenging in transcription biology and epigenetic gene regulatory control. Our data revealed that the complex had unanticipated roles in not only turning genes on, but perhaps just as important, keeping genes off at specific times—critical findings that could only have been possible using a genetic model system. Bioinformatic modeling identified multiple cell patterning, growth regulation and cellular differentiation pathways that were exquisitely sensitive to MLR complex regulation, providing important insight into how and when enhancers are marked to control the timing of gene expression during development.

Histone recognition and binding by the MLR complex is essential for proper enhancer regulation. This function is performed by a portion of the Cmi protein in Drosophila known as the PHD (plant homeodomain) cluster found in all MLR proteins. We have shown through extensive computational modeling that this domain likely folds into a specific structure that binds to small portions of the histones. Upon binding, the structure likely undergoes critical structural changes. We identified essential amino acid residues within the PHD region involved in the histone contacts using mutagenesis and biochemical assays. Our models for how this highly conserved domain functions in histone recognition, sets the stage for a more thorough mechanistic analysis of enhancer control. These studies are important for understanding the roles of this complex in both normal development and human disease.

This project has involved the training of numerous students from multiple institutions, including one PhD, two MS, 5 undergraduate and 3 high school students. Bioinformatics analyses were performed by undergraduate and MS students from Loyola University Chicago main campus through a training pipeline stablished by the PI. Structural/computational modeling involved both undergraduate students and emeritus faculty from Loyola and collaborators from several institutions, and our x-ray crystallography studies involve collaborations with an investigator and students from Wayne State University and the Argonne Laboratory. Vast amounts of high-throughput data generated by this project has been made available to the general scientific public.
